div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7358] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged, as if the voyage were commending at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibralter, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Malls arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea Fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: GERMANY AND THE NAVY.
div.p: The German papers do not hesitate to con- sider (say Reuter to-day) that the Emperor William's words in his speech at the opening of the Reichstag were aimed at Great Britain and France. It is, unfortunately, a fixed idea with a considerable proportion of the German people, and especially with those who have taken to heart their Kaiser's declaration that the future of Germany lies upon the water, that England means to destroy the German Fleet before it has become too powerful. Any man who seriously belives that England would ever enter upon a war of aggression for that end is profoundly ignorant of the temper of the British nation. We desire peace with all the world, and with Germany at least as much as with any other Power, for this simple reason- that, apart from the temporary set-back to her commercial activity, Germahy would have 'no' spoils to surrender to a victorious England. The game, in short, would not be worth the candle, because Germany posesses nothing that we could take from her which would be worth the taking. But has England nothing that Germany envies, nothing would be a rish prize for her? The question, surely, an- swers itself. There is the British Empire, which, as German Professors are never weary to tell- ing us, is bound, sooner or later, to go the way of all other Empires in history. "This is the heir; come, let us kill him, and the inheritance shall be ours." That, briefly, is the view of that section of German opinion, official and unofficial, which is responsible for the growth of the German Navy. If any one doubt that, let him recall the attitude of the German Press and public towards England during the Boer War. Nay, the actual preamble of the Navy Act of 1900 proves that the increase of the German Navy is specially directed against England. It says:- "Germany must have a fleet of such strength that a war against the mightiest Power would involve risks threaten- ing the supremacy of that Power." In the face of that declaration, and of the plain teaching of German and Prussian policy in the past, it is the obvious duty of the British Government so to order the distribution of the British Navy as to be prepared for all contin- gencies. That does not mean that we ought to, or that we shall, attack Germany for the deli- berate purpose of destroying her fleet before it becomes too strong; but it does mean that we shall take care that she shall not serve us as she served Austria in 1866 and France in 1870. If Germany distructs our intentions is it because she is concious that we have good reason to distruct hers. She knows- she must known- that we cannot choose but regard her with suspicion, because she herself, for years past, has made no secret of her belief that she is pre-destined to be the World Power of the Twentiath Century as England has been of the Nineteenth.

div.head: SUNLIGHT SOAP
div.p: Common Soaps reduce the Washing, Sunlight Soap preserves it.
It is Rapid, Pure, Sweet.
It stands in universal favour, for it is a perfect Soap, with- out any obnoxious or harmful features whatever.

div.head: THE KAISER'S SPEECH. AIMED AT ENGLAND OR FRANCE.

div.p: Following the Emperor's speech the press insists with remarkable unanimity on the necessity to augment the naval forces of the country.
(Reuter)
The German papers do not hesitate to con- sider that the Emperor's words concerning foreign relations were aimed at Great Britain and France.
(Reuter)
The English press accepts the speech of the German Emperor calmly, believing that it was prompted by a desire to increase the navy.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE CHANNEL FLEET. DIVIDED INTO TWO SQUADRONS.
div.p: The Admirality has decided to add five battleships from China to the Channel fleet, which is future will be divided into two squa- drons, of which these five will form what will practically be a North Sea Squadron, with a temporary base at Dover.
(Reuter)

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA. PANIC ON BOURSE.

div.p: There is a panic at the Bourse owning to the heavy fall in prices. Communications with Moscow are interupted, the telegraphists at that city having struck.
Two hundred and thirty soldiers of the Military School of Electricity have been arrest- ed and incarcerated in a fortress by four battalions.
(Reuter)
Frantic selling still continues at the Bourse to-day. Princes have reached the lowest points yet recorded.
(Reuter)
The postal and telegraph employees are on strike.
(Havas)
Naval Lieutenant Schmitt has taken com- mand of the mitinied squadron.
(Havas)

div.head: LIBERALS AND HOME RULE.
div.p: Speaking at Wisbech, Mr. Asquith said that there was no substantial difference between Liberals regarding Home Rule, but he did not believe that the re-introduction of the Home Rule Bill will form part of the policy of the Government.
(Reuter)

div.head: COTTON GROWING ASSOCIATION. ANTICIPATIONS FOR 1906.
div.p: At a meeting of shareholders of the Cotton Growing Association, held at Manchester, the directors states that the association expected to received cotton valued at £250,000 in 1906. It is found that West-Indian cotton is already superior to American.
(Reuter)

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Merchants, Tradesmen and others in Cairo wishing to do business with British firms are requested to send their names, addresses, and particulars of their businesses to Mr. Peter Black, "The Commercial Bureau," P.O. Box No. 50, Cairo.

div.head: KING ALFONSO'S MARRIAGE. WITH ENGLISH PRINCESS.
Madrid, November 29.
div.p: The "Correspondencia" announces the mar- riage of the King with Princess Victoria Euge- nie of Battenburg.
(Havas)

div.head: THE POWERS AT MITYLENE. SAILORS RE-EMBARKED.
Mitylene, November 29.
div.p: 60 international sailors landed here. 500 of these subsequently re-embarked, not being required.
(Reuter)

div.head: Nagasaki, November 29.
div.p: The Rossia, Gromoboi, and Bogatyr, of which nothing has been heard since the disturbances at Vladivostok on the 15th instant, arrived here to-day, having left in the midst of the rioting. There is much speculation as to the reason why they should leave at such a time.
(Reuter)

div.head: Banks in Egypt.
div.p: "M.D." is informed that no notice is taken of anonymous letters to the Editor.

div.head: Khedive's Accession Fete.
div.p: The total amount subscribed for the cele- bration of the anniversary of the Khedive's accession is now L.E. 456.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The Legislative Council will meet on Satur- day, when it will examine the Budget for 1906, the Financial Advisor's Note, and several other questions.

div.head: Cairo Police.
div.p: A native contemporary states that the Go- vernment has decided on suppressing the post of the Assistant Commandant of the Cairo City Police.

div.head: Egyptian Institute.
div.p: A meeting of the Institute will be held on Monday next at 3.30 p.m. when M. Geor- giades and Dr. Off will contributed a "Note corrective sur l'examen microscopique des sediments urinaires."

div.head: Concert.
div.p: Mme Bonucci-Carlesimo, the well-known pianist, will give a recital in the Lifonti con- cert-room, on Monday next, 4th inst. The programme is a very attractive on, and should draw a large number of local dilletanti.

div.head: English-Arabic Vocabulary.
div.p: We understand that Spiro Bey has in the press a second edition, revised and consider- ably enlarged, of his well-known English- Arabic Vocabulary of the spoken Arabic of Egypt, and that it will very soon appear.

div.head: Researched in Egypt.
div.p: The authorities at Oxford University have granted a sum of £50 out of the Craven Uni- versity Fund to Dr. Bernard P. Grenfell, Fellow of Queen's College, and Dr. Arthur S. Hunt, Fellow of Lincoln College, to enable them to continue their research in Egypt.

div.head: An Arabic Book on Dowries.
div.p: An Arabic booklet, entitled "Al Baineh," has been recently published by Selim Effendi Awad, secretary to the Wakfs' counsel, Alex- andria, comprising a historical survey of the dowry and some of its regulations and terms in the old Greek and Roman time, and its modern rules under French law, supplemented by some details of the Mohamedan law concern- ing the "Mahr." The little book appears to be useful to people interested in the subject of which it treats. The author concludes with the following remarks: "Young people can be seen everywhere seeking their fortunes through marriage, and many people prefer to remain bachelors with bright hopes of obtaining for- tunes of dowries, rather than marry a poor or little-moneyed girl, albeit she is pretty, polite, and well-educated. The young man who, in the course of searching for his better half, finds a beautiful, well-dowered, refined, and agreeable wife is one of the happiest of human beings."
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.
FEARS NO HONEST COMPETITION FOR QUALITY.
N.B. -- Inferior Brands now being offered to Managers of certain good circles.
Beware of evilly disposed competitors running down this very SUPERIOR BRAND OF BEER.

div.head: THE YACHT MAHROUSSA. ACTION AGAINST THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Sherriff Davidson in Glasgow issued an im- portant judgment on the 21st inst., in an action against the Khedive, who was sued for £2,000 by Mr. A. M. Gordon, naval architect and engineer, of Baltic Chamberg Wellington-street, Glasgow.

The action concerns the Khedive's steam yacht Mahrousse, the plaintiff averring that he was employed by the defendant in connection with certain alterations to be made on the yacht, and that he was to be paid £2,000 for preparing plans and seeing the work carried through.
Defendant states there were certain dealings between plaintif and the captain of the yacht, but he denied that plaintiff was employed to do the work.
An interesting point in connection with the case was that the yacht was arrested in the yard of Messrs. Inglis, Pointhouse, Glasgow.

Plaintiss submitted an application asking the court to apply to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs for a certificate to the effect that his Highness the Khedive was not an independent Sovereign, and was, therefore, subject to the jurisdiction of the court.
The Sheriff refused this application, but closed the record, and allowed a proof as to plaintiff's averment that he has arrested the property of the defendant to find jurisdiction.

div.head: THE PRINCES' CLAIM.
div.p: The Property Protection Society, formed to resist proposals injurious to the interest of property owners, show in the annual report just issued the range of their activites. Accompanying the report are documents deal- ing exhaustively with the claims made by the next-of-kin of his late Highness Ismail Khedive of Egypt against the Egyptian Government, including the joint opinion of Messrs. Asquith, Upjohn, and Nepean, to the effect "that the claims of the heirs of his Highness Ismail Pasha rest upon an equitable basis, and ought to be enforceable in a Court of Justice." It will be remembered that the claim is for six and a half millions, and that the defendants are the Egyptian Government, the Daira Sanieh of his Highness the Khedive, the Credit Foncier Egyptien, and the Daira Sanieh, Limited.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesterday morning his Highness the Khe- dive left Koubbeh for Montazah, where he will make a short stay with a view to inspect- ing his properties there and at Mariout.

div.head: GORDON COLLEGE AT KHARTOUM
div.p: A meeting of the general council of the Gordon Memorial College at Khartoum was held at Cannon-street Hotel, London, last week, Lord Hillingdon presiding. The chairman referred to a letter he had received from the Sirdar, Sir R. Wingate, strongly advocat- ing the appointment of three additional members to the executive committee of the Gordon Memorial College- namely, Sir William Mather, Mr. H.S. Wellcomb, and Sir Henry Craik. The chairman then moved a resolution that the executive committee be authorised to alter the deed-bill of July 11, 1899, which provides for the legal custody of the property occupied with the college, and other matters, so as to permit of the appointment of addition- al ordinary members to a total not exceeding ten, instead of seven as at present. This was seconded and passed unanimously.

div.head: NATIONAL HOTELS.
div.p: We learn that the issue of shares in the National Hotels and Residences Company, of which we had ocasion to speak a fort- night ago after the opening of the National Hotel, Cairo, will take place on Monday and Tuesday next, 4th and 5th prox. The new company has a capital of L.E. 200,000, divided into 50,000 shares of L.E. 4 each. This capital has been fully subscribed at par by the foun- ders, and only 30,000 shares, also at par, will be offered to the public. The board of directors is composed of Messrs. Antoun Bey Sabbagh, A. Colucci, and G. Valle Bey, of Cairo, and Neghib Hani, of Beyrout. Appli- cations of shares will be received by the Anglo-Egyptian Bank at Cairo and Alex- andria.

div.head: OPENING OF SAVOY HOTEL.
div.p: The Savoy Hotel opened its doors for the season on Monday, and we hear that there are so many application for suites and rooms that the management anticipate the best season on record. There are already about 50 visitors staying at the hotel, amongst them several well-known residents. The visitors already at the Savoy include: Rear-Admiral Hon. H. Lambton, Capt. Sir George Warrender, Bart, R.N., Mrs. Laidlow, Mrs. Chas. Cochrane and Miss Cochrane, Mr. and Mrs. Palmer C. Rick- etts, U.S.A., Mr. L.D. Ricketts, Judge George S. Batcheller and Miss Batcheller, Mr. Victor Thomas, Paris, Mme. and Mlle Ravaut, Pairs, Mr. and Mrs. Scot-Dalgleish, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mond and family, London, Mr. and Mme Felix Green, Mr. and Mme Casdagli, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bell, New York, Mr and Mme W.G. Van Horne, Marquis de Fior- vanti, Mr. Smiley, Mrs. E.A. Lyman, U.S.A. Sir Charles Scotter, and Mr. and Mrs. Fred Scotter, London.

div.head: BANKING IN EGYPT. ANGLO-EGYPTIAN MEEETING.
div.p: The nineteenth ordinary general meeting of the Englo-Egyptian Bank (limited) was held yesterday week at 27, Clement's lane, E.C., Mr. Thomas Usborne presiding.

The Chairman said the total net profit exceeding £100,000. Although that constituted a record, he warned the shareholders that those records could not go on forever. For the last fifteen years or so banking in Egypt had been few, and no bad debts whatever had been made on loans secured by Egyptian real pro- perty. It was almost difficult to make bad debts in a country where the land and other real property were always rising in value and the bulk of the people were getting daily richer, but that position of affairs would reach its zenith one day, and although he would not have them attach too much importance to his opinion, he though the zenith had been reach- ed, and that the value of property was now too high. There were now ten banks, the majority of them important, at work in Egypt, and the directors heard of another- an English one- the prospectus of which would be issued very shortly. The reserve fund was equal to the paid-up capital, £500,000, there were other small reserve funds amounting to £40,000, and they were carrying forward £36,000. With the consent of the shareholders the board intended contributing £50,000 to a proposed pension fund, and to add to it each year until it amounted to £100,000, when they expected the interest would meet the pensions. He concluded by moving the adoption of the report, which was seconded by Mr. H.A. Richardson, and carried unanimously.

div.head: BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Creville, manager of the Bank of Egypt, Cairo, is resigning his post in order to take up a high position with the New Egyptian Com- pany, Mr. Greville's successor will in all pro- bability be Mr. Davidson, amanger of the Fauk's Khartoum branch.

div.head: ABBASSIEH OASIS.
div.p: Borings for water to the depth of about 50 metres have been made on the estate of the Abbassieh Oasis, but have yielded no satisfac- tory results as yet. Wherever the water has been found it has been brackish.
The plans of the new electric railway from Cairo to the Abbassieh Oasis have just been completed and will shortly be submitted to the Government for approval.

div.head: P. & O. COMPANY.
div.p: The directors, after providing for the usual dividend at the rate of 5 per cent, per annum, on the Preferred stock, recommend a dividen on the Deferred stock of 6 1/2 per cent for the six months, and a bonus of 3 per cent, mak- ing with the interim dividend paid in June a total distribution on the Deferred stock of 13 per cent for the year. A year ago the distribu- ton was the same.

div.head: SHRAGER BROS.' FAILURE.
div.p: In the London Bankruptcy Court this day week, before Mr. E.S. Grey, Official Receiver, the first meeting of creditors was held under the failure of Shrager Bros., merchants, of 4 Lloyd's avennue, E.C.

The chairman repoted that the firm had carried on business at Calcutta, Colombo, Singapore, Alexandria, and Broome, West Australia. The business was established in 1888 and the turnover had amounted to three of four millions of pounds a year. Proofs amounting to £57,809 had been sent in, but he (the Official Receiver) was unable to state the exact amount of the indebtedness or assets until accounts had been received from the various foreign branches of the business. The London house acted as buying and selling agents for the other branches, the principal lines of business being in jute, gunnies, castor oil, rice, bone-meal, and shellac. The failure was caused by the apparent excellence of this year's jute crop. The London house received large orders from Calcutta to sell for an expected fall in prices; but early in October last, owing to floods in the Goalando district and the disorganisation of railway traffic, Calcutta could not get delivery of jute, and prices rose everywhere. The Official Assignee of Bengal was in possession fo the Indian estate, and it was for the creditors to consider the expediency of having a single adminis- tration.
After some discussion, a resolution was unanimously carried in favor of this course being adopted, and Mr. C.J. March, chartered accountant, was appointed trustee.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Carib Prince, from London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Wednesday, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on 3rd December.
The Moss liner Philae sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Sun- day morning with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: MYSTERIOUS MURDER. MAN'S BODY FOUND AT GABBARI.
div.p: Two native women and six girls were engaged in gathering snails on Tuesday after- noon in Gabbari Gardens, when they were horrified to find the dead body of a man lying on the ground. The man had evidently been strangled. His hands were tied behind his back, and a blue silk handkerchief was firmly fastened round his neck.

At the sight of the body, one of the girls promptly ran home and informed her brother of the lugubrious discovery. The latter hasten- ed to apprise the police, who were soon on the spot and opened an enquiry.

The murdered man has been identified as Andria Boryas, an Ottoman subject, 35 years of age, and a cook by profession. He arrived at Alexandria last Thursday from Turkey. A sum of about 30 dollars was found on his body by the police.

Several arrests on suspicion have been made, but no definite clue to the crime has been discovered. It is not known either whether the murder was committed at the spot where the dead man's body had been brought there from the scene of the tragedy.
The police are actively pursuing their in- cestigation.

div.head: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Three days ago four men servants who are employed on the Um Rus were assaulted by a band of robbers as they were taking baggage, papers, etc., laden on four camels, to the mine in the mountains. After a fight the attacking party succeeded in obtaining possession of the property and camels, and the men in charge returned and informed the police of the occurrence.

Steps were immediately taken for the arrest of the thieves, and men were stationed at every outlet from the mountain. After two days search three of the robbers were arrested with the property and two of the camels in their possession, the other two having been killed. Search is going on for a fourth man, who was the leader of the gang. The men in custody will be brought to Keneh to-day, and an enquiry opened in the affair.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE.
div.p: The third pupil concert of the Alexandria Conservatoire took place last Thursday night and surpassed in excellence the two previous ones. The result was most satisfactory in proving the efficiency of the teaching. The appreciating of the immense audience which thronged the concert hall and vestibule must have greatly delighted Professor Colella and his hard-worked staff. Work want on inces- santly all through the hot, damp summer and autumn, and great credit is due to both pro- fessors and pupils for the successful issue of their arduous studies. When one considers the small pittance received by the masters per month, and the miserably small, stuffy rooms at their disposal (which do not even belong to them but are kindly lent by the University committee), we can but feel astonished at the amount of courage and patience that must have been expended to attain such a result The programme was replete with excellent and interesting numbers, vocal and instrumental, and the selections from Mozart's 'Requiem" and Wagner's 'Apostle's Supper' were quite surprisingly well given. The Financial Ad- viser's note, which appeared on the after- noon of the concert, was most opportune, and gave great encouragement to the com- mittee, Professor Colella, and his devoted staff of professors, as also to the small band of 50 adherents. There are "better days coming" for the Conservatoire, and all honor is due to those who have manfully stuck to their guns in the days of distress and opposition.

div.head: GUM.
div.p: Gum Arabic.- Of 124 packages 10 sold, fair palish sifted Turkey sorts.

Gum Benjamin.- of 126 cases 25 sold, fair Sumatra 2nds slightly dark at ends 8L 5s, medium ditto old fracture at 7l _s 6d, good 3rds at 5l, dark Saigon garblings at 80s, low Pa- lemberg 4ths at 2s 6d, if pay charges.
Gum Elemi.- 28 cases bought in.
Gum Euphorbium.- 13 packages bought in.
Gum Guaiacum.- 1 case sold, subject, at 8 1/2d.
Gum Kino.- 2 cases bought in.
Gum Myrrh.- 21 packages bought into.
Gum Olibanum.- Of 11 cases 6 sold, good, bold sifting without reserve at 16s.

div.head: IVORY.
div.p: The following quantities have arrived to date for the quarterly sales, January, 1906.
Deliveries since October auctions 44 tons.

div.head: ADVANCE PORT SUDAN. A TRIPLET OF FIRST EVENTS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: We have to chronicle a triplet of First Events. The quiet and peaceful existence at Port Sudan has been broken. We have had a 7,000- ton ship at anchor in our quickly improv- ing harbour, we have actually had a concert, and, miabile dictu, prepared for a real cricket match. It is true that some few days back, we had an epidemic of bruglaries whcih upset the monotony of life somewhat, and the chance of capturing some enterprising burglar sent one to the heated couch, with subdued excitement and apprehension of all sorts of contingencies, but Fielden Bey issued an edict to the effect that after 9 p.m. (or curfew hour) all people out in the highway and byeways were to carry lamps, or suffer such fines and penalties as he, the High Official aforesaid, might impose, and Allah is God, and Kismet is Fate. Lo__ the Faith- ful no longer lose their property, and the Feringhi High or unimportant, can once more sleep the sleep of the hard worked and just. Actually, the very room of the Majesty of law and order (civil and military) was entered, and a whole trunk of kit removed. Luckily, the Inspector woke up, and the enemy fled, pursued by a good six feet six of solid English wrath, not to mention a rear rank of a very angry Bey and sundry other Government officers woken up from their dreams of cool winds or English snows. So, robberies having ceased, the arrival of a band on the S.S. Afghanistan (Capt. Moore) was promptly made use of, and an engagement as promptly followed, and on the evening of the 15th inst. Fielded Bey and the members of the engineers' mess at Government House asked for the pleasure of the company of some fifty of the residents, at a concert to be held on that date (carriages at 10.30 p.m. might have been added, but our first cariolet and swarthy Jehu have yet to arrive) and The Residence was very prettily decorated by the aid of many flags known and unknown to students of these national trophies, and kudos goes to Messrs. Barry and Campbell, the artists concerned. The orchestra, which deserves mention, was quite a pleasant surprise, for not only did they tackle a programme of distinct class, but played the numbers with well-drilled ensemble and evident respect to the baton of their chef d'orchestre. Of a long programme, the intermezzo of Cavalleria Rusti- cana was delightfully played and well merited the encore. Due appreciation of difference between forte and piano was shown, and the crescendos were distinctly not only weel done but played with artistic enjoyment; other successes were the rarely heard ballet music from Gounod's Faust, Braga's Serenata (for violincello and piano), an excellent violin solo, and the pretty Salut d'Armour." The concert terminated with the good old British songs "The old Folks at Home" and "The Song that Reached my Heart," arranged by the conductor, the oboe and clarinet taking the solos, and the pizzicato accompaniments being dainty and effective. At the conclusion, Fielden Bey was seen to congratulate Mr. Coke on the work of his men. And they deserved it. The audience of over 50 was enthusiastic, even the placud Mohamedans waking up to applaud each item. I ought to mention that the orchestra is going out to play at Bombay, at the new Taj Mahal Hotel there- a treat for its patrons.

The harbour works are progressing, and in due time the quays will be ready to receive some ten steamers alongside of them. New houses, too, are springing up on all sides, albeit there is no ground tenure as yet. Until we get an hotel, and electric light, we shall nto be happy.

A great disappointment occurred on the 18th inst. The town had challenged the S.S. Afghanistan to play the first game of cricket ever known here. Every preparation was made, a nice tent, iced drinks galore, and hospitality in every shape were, at the hands of our Sports Club, conspicuous. At the last moment the captain of our opponents, Mr. Coke, who is an old school and county player, we heard, turned up to say that the ship was due to sail at mid-day. The law of a ship captain is like unto that of the Medes and Persians, so we could but stand the musical cricketer a cold doch an dorris and wish him every luck in the Farther East.

A new firm has arrived, but this time it is not a Greek one. The new arrival, Mr. Warren, is an experienced African traveller, and he is a genial fellow and full of anecdote, who should cut out some of the Greek merchants. We have room for more english commerical enter- prise. I ought to add that as there are some 300 out-of-works- all Greeks or Italians- no one can land and stay here without a passport.
A COLONIAL SCOT.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil
H.H. Prince Djemil Toussoun embarked for Marseilles yesterday on the S.S. Hohenzollegn.
Sir Vincent Corbett has been spending Bey- ram at Mena House.
Bernard Pasha, Financial Secretery to the Sudan Government, left for Khartoum yester- day.
M. Blariaux, late Belgian judge in teh Na- tive Court of 1st Insurance at Cairo, has return- ed to Egypt and will practice as a barrister before the Mized Courts.
M. Empein, the great Belgian capitalist, is expected to arrive at Cairo next month.
Mr. and Miss Bullock have left Cairo, and will be absent about three weeks.
General Sir Augstus and Lady Hemming, with Miss Hemming, are staying at the Hotel d'Angleterre.
Mr. and Mrs. Borton have left for Upper Egypt and are expected back in Alexandria about Christmas.
Professor Finders Petrie is leaving Cairo in order to conduct his Egyptological work on the east side of the Delta, and will remain in that part of egypt during the season.

Sir Philip Burne-Jones is painting for Lady Palmer a novel picture-portrait of Countess Feo Gleichen in her studio in St. James's Palace, for presentation to Countess Valda Gleichen (Countess Feo's sister) on her mar- riage next week. Sir Philip is painting Coun- tess Feo in her working dress and long white apron as she stands at work on a statue.

Countess Valda Gleichen's fiance, Mr. Ma- chell, says the "Tatler," was a nephew of "The Captain," whose career was a romance of the Turf. When he was a subaltern in Ireland the famous sportsman was a £100 foot race bought an Irish horse with the money, and started on the hgih road to fortune.

His Irish horse, the famous Bacchus, was the Prince of Wales's Stakes at Newmarket shortly after and over that he netted about £12,000. His next great coup was when Mr. Chaplin's Hermit won the Derby in a snow- storm in 1887. Capt. Machell was managing Mr. Chaplin's stables at the time, and left the course a wealthy man.

After that he continued to prosper, and eventually bought back Crackenthorpe, the old family seat of the Machells, in Cumberland, Young Mr. Machell's grandmother was a great beauty, and her children and grandchildren all had their share of good looks.
M. Saint-Saens, the famous French composer, who is coming to Egypt, will spend the greater part of the winter here.
Sir Herbert Stephen is coming out early in December.
Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley are staying a few days in Paris en route to Egypt.
Major and the Hon. Mrs. Noel Lowry Corry intend wintering here, and are bringing the Hon. Lilah O'Brien with them.
Mrs. H.A. Withers has arrived at the Na- tional Hotel, Cairo, for the season.

Among the latest arrivals at the savoy, Port Said, we notice Lady Strong and party, Major Ricarde-Scover, Mr. Ch. Christian, Mr. E. Dicey, Mr. S. Cohen, Mr. Brodhurst, Mr. Lerd, Mr. Schrager, Mr. and Mrs. Houghton, Mr. Hill. Mr. Waldemeier, Mr. and Mrs. Sterry, Mr. and Mrs. Peares Derocold, Lady Evelyn Jung, Miss Michell, Capt. Jung, Mr. Nemoon, Miss Hartnoll, Mr. Crack, Mrs. Smith, Mr. John Blue, Hon. A. Lindley, Capt. Wilson.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.
